item.title: France’s interior minister visits Algeria amid hopes of thawing relations
item.description: French Interior Minister Laurent Nunez visited Algeria on Monday in what could signal a thaw in relations between the two countries. Under his predecessor, Bruno Retailleau, France tightened entry conditions for Algerian diplomats and threatened retaliation if Algeria refused to take back its citizens ordered to leave French territory. Ties worsened further after France recognised Morocco’s sovereignty over Western Sahara, a region at the heart of a decades-long dispute.

item.title: Bangladesh : Muhammad Yunus annonce la démission du gouvernement provisoire quatre jours après les élections législatives
item.description: Vendredi, la commission électorale avait proclamé largement gagnant le Parti nationaliste du Bangladesh aux premières élections législatives organisées dans le pays depuis la chute de Sheikh Hasina, en 2024.

item.title: « Ça faisait plus de deux ans que j’attendais, et là il fallait partir d’un coup » : entre Gaza et l’Egypte, les évacuations de patients palestiniens commencent au ralenti
item.description: Rawan Joudeh, une mère de famille palestinienne atteinte d’une tumeur au cerveau, a dû partir en urgence pour recevoir des soins en Egypte, après une très longue attente. Elle a pu sortir grâce à la réouverture du poste-frontière de Rafah, mais compte revenir dans l’enclave au plus vite.

item.title: Bangladesh's interim leader Yunus resigns, handing power to elected government
item.description: Bangladesh's interim leader Muhammad Yunus stepped down on Monday before handing over to an elected government led by the Bangladesh Nationalist Party and its leader Tarique Rahman. Bangladeshi voters held national elections and endorsed sweeping democratic reforms via referendum in February following the overthrow of Sheikh Hasina and her iron-fisted government.

item.title: En Suède, un homme soupçonné d’avoir contraint son épouse à se prostituer avec au moins 120 hommes
item.description: Placé en détention depuis le mois d’octobre, le mari, âgé d’une soixantaine d’années, a été interpellé après que son épouse eut signalé les faits à la police.

item.title: French police raid offices of ex-culture minister over Epstein links
item.description: French investigators raided the offices of former culture minister Jack Lang on Monday, prosecutors said, as the fallout grows over his relationship with sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Lang was forced out of his post as head of the Arab World Institute (IMA) earlier this month over alleged financial ties with Epstein.

item.title: Rubio meets with pro-Trump allies Orban and Fico on Europe trip
item.description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio met with Hungary’s Viktor Orban and Slovakia’s Prime Minister Robert Fico during his whirlwind trip to Europe. Orban and Fico are widely seen as two of the most Eurosceptic and pro-Trump leaders within the European Union. “Donald Trump has been endorsing like-minded, conservative nationalist leaders around the world,” FRANCE 24 International Affairs Editor Kethevane Gorjestani said in an analysis, noting that this departs from precedent, as US presidents usually avoid taking sides in other countries’ domestic politics.

item.title: Ukraine ex-energy minister named suspect in laundering investigation
item.description: Ukraine's former energy minister German Galushchenko has been formally named as a suspect in a high-profile money laundering probe, investigators said Monday. The announcement comes one day after Galushchenko was detained by law enforcement attempting to leave Ukraine, and is the latest development in a corruption scandal in the energy sector that rocked the government last year. FRANCE 24's Emmanuelle Chaze reports from Kharkiv.

item.title: EN DIRECT, guerre en Ukraine : la Russie a lancé un nombre record de missiles balistiques sur le pays en janvier, selon Kiev
item.description: Les forces russes ont lancé 91 missiles balistiques en direction de l’Ukraine en janvier, ce qui constitue le chiffre mensuel le plus élevé depuis le début de la guerre. Une délégation ukrainienne a pris la route de Genève pour un nouveau cycle de négociations avec des représentants des Etats-Unis et de la Russie.

item.title: Trump committed to Hungarian PM Orban's success, Rubio says
item.description: President Donald Trump is committed to the ​success of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban because his leadership is crucial for US national interests, US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said on Monday, ​offering ‌a strong US endorsement for the long-time nationalist ⁠leader who is facing an election in April.

item.title: L’impasse politique de l’Irak, coincé entre les chiites et les Etats-Unis
item.description: La nomination de l’ancien premier ministre Nouri Al-Maliki de nouveau à ce poste par le Cadre de coordination, en majorité chiite, déplaît à Washington, qui le juge trop proche de l’Iran.

item.title: Can the Winter Olympics survive the climate crisis?
item.description: This year, the Winter Olympics are taking place in the north of Italy, against a backdrop of climate change and rising temperatures, which are casting a shadow over the future of the Games. Like many of its predecessors, Milan Cortina is relying on artificial snow, pumping 50,000 cubic metres of water, or the equivalent of 20 Olympic-sized pools. Our environment editor Valérie Dekimpe tells us more.

item.title: Icelandic musician Ásgeir on his new free-flowing album 'Julia'
item.description: Iceland's award-winning Ásgeir rose to fame over the last decade thanks to his stunning falsetto voice and intricate guitar melodies. He popped by the FRANCE 24 studios to tell Marjorie Hache about his fifth album "Julia", which is the first he has composed fully in English. We also hear from Australia's Chet Faker and take a look at electroclash queen Peaches' new release "No Lube So Rude".

item.title: Flying oranges: Italian town celebrates carnival with historic street battle
item.description: A town in northern Italy has started celebrating carnival with its annual Battle of the Oranges where people hurl the fruit at each other for fun.

item.title: Russia using Africans as 'cannon fodder' in Ukraine: INPACT/All Eyes on Wagner
item.description: Russia is accused of "aggressively recruiting" people from across the African continent to fight on the front lines in Ukraine. The investigation unit INPACT/All Eyes on Wagner says it has evidence of nearly 1,500 soldiers from 35 countries who have been recruited by Russia, over 300 of whom who have been killed in battle. The organisation says the real numbers are probably far higher as Russia has set up a fraud travel agency to con people into travelling there with the promise of high salaries, only to find themselves serving in the Russian army. We spoke to Lou Osborn in Perspective.

item.title: Dana Eden, productrice israélienne de la série « Téhéran », retrouvée morte à Athènes
item.description: « Tout semble indiquer qu’il s’agit d’un suicide », a rapporté un porte-parole de la police grecque. La société de production qu’elle codirigeait a démenti toutes les rumeurs autour d’un éventuel meurtre.

item.title: Live: Ukraine names ex-minister Galushchenko suspect in laundering probe
item.description: Ukrainian investigators named former energy minister German Galushchenko as a suspect in a laundering probe after alleging they found approximately $12 million in bank accounts linked to his family, investigators said Monday. Galushchenko was accused in November of taking part in a $100-million kickback scheme from contractors building fortifications to defend energy infrastructure against Russian attacks. Follow our liveblog for the latest.

item.title: Five injured as Swiss train derails in heavy snow
item.description: One passenger was taken to hospital after the derailment, which police say could have been caused by an avalanche.

item.title: Unlocking the secrets of glaciers: Scientists, mountaineers on a climate rescue mission
item.description: Glaciers are vital to Earth's water supplies, yet they are being pushed to the brink of collapse. Half of the world's glaciers could disappear by the end of the century. A French mountain climber is putting her experience to use by helping scientists collect ice samples from major glaciers around the world. Living and dormant species found within them could provide vital clues in the fight against global warming. FRANCE 24's Juliette Alfano, Valérie Dekimpe and Alexandra Renard report.

item.title: 'M23 and Rwanda' to blame for latest violence in DR Congo: US senior adviser for Africa
item.description: In an interview with FRANCE 24, US Senior Adviser for Africa Massad Boulos blamed "the M23 and Rwanda" for the latest violence in DR Congo, calling it a "serious breach" of the Washington accord signed in 2025. The US was "extremely disappointed" by the M23 takeover of Uvira, he said, although M23 forces have since partially withdrawn. Boulos did not rule out US sanctions against Rwandan President Paul Kagame, adding that he still "hopes" the Rwandan leader can be trusted.

item.title: Rubio shows US support for Orban ahead of elections in Hungary
item.description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio hailed Viktor Orban's leadership during a visit to Budapest on Monday, ahead of elections threatening the nationalist prime minister's hold on power. Orban is facing heavy competition for the the April 12 legislative elections in Hungary with polls suggesting his Fidesz party is trailing opposition leader Peter Magyar's TISZA. FRANCE 24's Angela Diffley brings you this analysis.

item.title: North Korea’s Kim Jong Un may designate daughter Ju Ae as successor
item.description: South Korea’s spy agency reported that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un may be preparing his daughter, Ju Ae, to succeed him, fueling speculation over whether the teenager is being groomed as his successor. Over the past three years, Ju Ae has appeared alongside her father at an expanding range of events – including missile tests, military anniversaries, and major national celebrations – signaling that the state propaganda apparatus is gradually increasing her visibility. FRANCE 24's Jan Camenzind Broomby reports.

item.title: Navalny's mother says she always knew he was murdered after poison finding
item.description: On the second anniversary of his death, Lyudmila Navalnaya says her son did not "simply die in prison".

item.title: En Allemagne, la stagnation de l’emploi cache une profonde mutation du travail
item.description: Alors que les jobs industriels disparaissent à un rythme spectaculaire outre-Rhin, les recrutements se font désormais dans les services publics, le social et la santé. Et pour des postes moins productifs, moins rémunérés et souvent à temps partiel.

item.title: Dans les montagnes tunisiennes, l’interminable lutte contre les cellules djihadistes
item.description: Dans la région de Kasserine, bastion de l’insurrection djihadiste dans les années 2010, soldats et policiers patrouillent jour et nuit. L’élimination, le 22 janvier, d’une cellule terroriste qui projetait des attaques ravive la crainte d’un retour de la violence.

item.title: East Asia celebrates Year of the Horse with parades and festivities
item.description: People in Taiwan, China, Vietnam, Malaysia, and other countries across the world welcomed the Year of the Horse on Monday evening. Millions traveled home to celebrate with their families, as the holiday is considered a time of reunion. To mark the occasion, grand parades, light shows, and performances were held across East Asia. People hung lanterns, exchanged red envelopes filled with money, and enjoyed festive banquets.

item.title: Iran says US has developed 'more realistic' stance on nuclear issue ahead of Geneva talks
item.description: Iran's foreign ministry said on Monday that it believed the US' position on Tehran's nuclear weapons pile had become "more realistic" ahead of talks between the two countries in Geneva. The talks come as Iran's Revolutionary Guards begin military drills in the Straight of Hormuz and US President Donald Trump sent a second aircraft carrier to the Middle East to ratchet up military pressure.

item.title: French govt accuses hard left of being responsible for far-right activist's death
item.description: France's government accused the hard left Monday of being partly responsible for the killing of a far-right activist last week, an accusation that has been refuted by France Unbowed. Quentin Deranque, 23, died of his wounds after being attacked Thursday on the sidelines of a far-right protest against a left-wing politician speaking at a university in the city of Lyon. FRANCE 24's Politics Editor Marc Perelman brings you this analysis.

item.title: India hosts AI summit with Macron expected to attend
item.description: A global artificial intelligence summit kicked off in New Delhi on Monday with big issues on the agenda, from job disruption to child safety, although some attendees warned the broad focus could make concrete commitments from world leaders less likely. Some 20 world leaders including French President Emmanuel Macron is expected to attend, FRANCE 24's Navodita Kumari said, adding that India is looking to underscore the fact that it is the first time that any summit on AI at this scale is held in the global south.

item.title: A cultural stroll through Paris with actor Michel Boujenah and Lilly Wood & the Prick
item.description: This week on Paris des Arts, Valérie Fayolle sits down with actor and comedian Michel Boujenah. He's currently starring in "Toute la famille que j'aime" ("The whole family I love"), a witty comedy at the Théâtre des Variétés. Lilly Wood & the Prick also feature in this edition as they return with a fifth album "Christina", 10 years after the worldwide success of "Prayer in C".

item.title: 'It's never too late': Savannah Guthrie's new plea for mother's release as FBI analyses glove
item.description: The FBI says it recovered a DNA sample from the glove, which was found in a field a few miles from Guthrie's home.

item.title: Pressure grows for release of remaining Venezuelan political prisoners
item.description: An NGO says hundreds of people remain behind bars despite US pressure US to speed up their release.

item.title: Kenya strike delays flights at international hub airport
item.description: Authorities say they have put in place contingency measures as a labour dispute affects travel.

item.title: Madagascar : au moins 59 morts à la suite du passage du cyclone Gezani
item.description: Le cyclone a semé la destruction dans le nord-est du pays, accompagné de rafales qui ont atteint jusqu’à 250 km/h. Quinze personnes sont par ailleurs portées disparues.

item.title: Year of the Horse: China prepares to celebrate Spring Festival
item.description: 2026 marks the Year of the Horse in China and across East Asia, as people prepare to celebrate the region’s most important holiday. Also known as the Spring Festival, it is a time for family reunions, with officials expecting around 9 billion trips nationwide as people travel home to celebrate.

item.title: Death of French activist Quentin is a 'turning point' in politics
item.description: PRESS REVIEW – Monday, February 16: We look at reactions in France after the death of Quentin Deranque, a French activist close to the far right. He died of his injuries after being attacked at a protest over a speech given by a far-left MEP at Lyon's political science university. Also, five countries including Britain are mulling extra sanctions on Russia over a report that a deadly frog toxin killed Alexei Navalny. Plus: Olympics records tumble for France, Norway, Italy and Great Britain at the Winter Games.

item.title: Mort d’Alexeï Navalny : la Russie juge « biaisées et infondées » les accusations européennes d’empoisonnement
item.description: Le principal opposant de Vladimir Poutine a été « empoisonné » en prison par le régime russe, selon une enquête menée par cinq pays, dont la France.

item.title: Affaire Epstein : des perquisitions menées à l’Institut du monde arabe dans le cadre de l’enquête visant Jack Lang
item.description: Si aucune charge ne pèse à ce stade contre Jack Lang, président démissionnaire de l’IMA, son nom est mentionné des centaines de fois dans des échanges avec Jeffrey Epstein, et les documents révèlent des liens d’intérêt. « Je n’ai rien à cacher », a réagi M. Lang.

item.title: Giant robot tribute to Brazil's President Lula leads start of Rio Carnival
item.description: Rio de Janeiro's iconic Carnival parades begin with a tribute to Brazil's President Lula, illustrating his rise from poverty to power.

item.title: Après la Conférence de Munich sur la sécurité, le devoir d’unité des Européens
item.description: Le constat d’éloignement durable entre les Etats-Unis et l’Union européenne, qui ressort du discours de Marco Rubio prononcé samedi en Allemagne, impose en retour la nécessité aux Européens de ne pas se montrer divisés.

item.title: ByteDance to curb AI video app after Disney legal threat
item.description: Videos featuring Spider-Man and other characters which are Disney's intellectual property have gone viral since Seedance's update.

item.title: Nigeria warns against enlisting abroad after reports of deaths in Ukraine
item.description: The authorities say a growing number of citizens are being illegally recruited to fight elsewhere.

item.title: En Hongrie, l’échec des politiques natalistes de Viktor Orban
item.description: Malgré les mesures instaurées par le premier ministre hongrois depuis son arrivée au pouvoir, en 2010, la natalité recule et la population est tombée en 2025 sous la barre des 9,5 millions de personnes.

item.title: Trump eyes Venezuela visit – but obstacles to his oil plan remain
item.description: The US president wants American energy firms to start extracting the crude but they are reluctant.

item.title: Suisse : un train a déraillé à Goppenstein, faisant cinq blessés, selon la police
item.description: « Au moment des faits, 29 personnes se trouvaient à bord. Selon les informations actuelles, cinq personnes ont été blessées », a détaillé la police du canton du Valais.

item.title: L’Allemagne juge « insuffisants » les efforts de la France pour augmenter les dépenses de défense et l’appelle à « faire des économies », notamment dans le social
item.description: Evoquant l’objectif affiché des pays de l’OTAN d’atteindre au moins 5 % de leur PIB pour leurs dépenses de sécurité d’ici à 2035, le ministre des affaires étrangères allemand a jugé qu’il y avait « des progrès à faire ».

item.title: What is the dart frog toxin allegedly used to kill Alexei Navalny?
item.description: The toxin, epibatidine, can be found in frogs in the wild in South America or manufactured in a lab.

item.title: Bondi Beach shooting accused faces court for the first time
item.description: The 24-year-old faces 59 charges, including 15 counts of murder and one of committing a terrorist attack.

item.title: Female Israeli soldiers rescued after being chased by ultra-Orthodox men
item.description: The two women were helped by police after being forced to run from a mob in the city of Bnei Brak.

item.title: Le ministre de l’intérieur, Laurent Nuñez, à Alger pour tenter de décrisper la relation franco-algérienne
item.description: Après des mois de tensions, le ministre de l’intérieur est attendu à Alger, lundi 16 février, pour une visite de deux jours. M. Nuñez entend se concentrer sur les dossiers sécuritaires prioritaires pour les deux pays.
